values.alignmentText: Forest reserves and the Mekong remain stunning, but slash-and-burn agriculture erodes access to pristine nature.
Hotter monsoons, Mekong dam impacts, and drought stress keep climate risk uncomfortably high.
Six sticky monsoon months with 35°C+ highs clash with the family’s mild-weather preference.
Crop burning and regional haze push PM2.5 above WHO limits each dry season.
Floods and landslides frequently disrupt rural provinces, and urban drainage is limited.
March–May averages hover around 24–35 °C (75–95 °F) with oppressive humidity before the rains.
April and May often sit at 33–37°C (91–99°F) with high humidity, requiring constant cooling.
September–November ease slightly to 22–31 °C (72–88 °F) as rains taper, yet humidity persists.
Dry-season highs around 25–28°C (77–82°F) feel pleasant, though nights stay warm.
Laos is landlocked; sandy Mekong riverbanks near Vang Vieng and Don Khon offer swims but lack true coastal amenities.
Without a coastline, river swimming depends on Mekong currents that can be murky and cool during the dry season.
Karst mountains, waterfalls like Kuang Si, and river islands deliver dramatic scenery and easy access to outdoor excursions.
Monthly minimum wages near $150 USD cannot cover international school fees or housing upgrades.
Local developers often earn under $15k USD, so sustaining US income requires remote contracts.
Government digitization projects hire a handful of .NET devs, but the market is tiny.
Ruby is virtually absent from the local tech stack outside of a few regional startups.
Most companies rely on short business visas; long-term sponsorship is rare and bureaucratic.
GDP growth is fast but from a low base, with heavy reliance on hydropower concessions.
Fiber exists in Vientiane, yet outages and power fluctuations mean Trey needs backup plans.
Workdays tend to finish by early evening, and family gatherings are culturally important.
Labour law sets a 48-hour week (8–5 with long lunch), and overtime compliance is patchy in private firms.
Labor law grants 15 days, but smaller firms may only honor the legal floor.
Companies rarely go beyond the minimum, so extended US trips require negotiation.
Daily rhythms feel laid back compared to US metros, matching Sarah’s slower pace goal.
Schools often run half-day shifts, requiring parents to juggle midday pickups or hire help.
Weekends highlight river markets and temple visits, though heat can limit outdoor time.
Extended-family networks are strong and neighbors look out for children, yet modern family amenities are sparse.
Conservative social norms and lack of legal recognition make openly polyamorous relationships risky.
Respect for elders and obedience are emphasized, with schools expecting parents to support rote learning over experimentation.
Vientiane’s small size and low traffic feel manageable, but playgrounds and kid-focused museums are limited.
Public schools struggle with teacher shortages; bilingual or international programs exist only in major towns at high cost.
Urban areas offer a few private preschools, yet curriculum quality and English support vary widely.
Formal childcare subsidies are minimal, with most families relying on relatives rather than state programs.
Foreign families must arrange private nannies or pricey international nurseries with little regulatory oversight.
Enrollment is high but instruction quality and resources—especially in rural schools—lag regional peers.
Non-citizens generally need to enroll in international schools charging tuition comparable to Bangkok.
A handful of Lao-Thai and French international schools exist, but seats are limited and fees steep.
Labour law mandates maternity leave and some allowances, yet benefits remain modest and poorly enforced.
Foreign workers rarely receive statutory family benefits beyond what employers voluntarily offer.
National University of Laos and sector institutes provide pathways, though research capacity and teaching quality are modest.
Programs in English are sparse and most expatriates look to Thailand or online study for degrees.
Women participate in markets and civil service, yet traditional expectations around caregiving remain strong.
Legal recognition of gender diversity is absent, and expressing non-binary identities outside nightlife scenes is uncommon.
Domestic violence laws exist but enforcement is weak; women face barriers in leadership and land ownership.
Ideal femininity stresses modest dress, family duty, and Buddhist merit-making.
Men are expected to provide financially and maintain calm authority, leaving limited space for alternative models.
The Buddhist festival calendar, slow Mekong travel, and craft villages create a distinctive cultural rhythm to explore.
Lao is essential; English is limited outside tourism and NGO circles.
The single-party state maintains conservative social norms with little space for dissent.
Official discourse embraces socialist solidarity, yet most citizens focus pragmatically on commerce and family.
Theravada Buddhism guides most civic life, but the state is secular enough that non-belief draws little attention if discrete.
Public displays of affection are discouraged and sex education is limited, signaling conservative norms.
There’s social tolerance in Vientiane nightlife, but no legal protections or recognition.
Village-style mutual aid and expat volunteer groups make it easy to plug into communal projects.
Many Laotians take pride in being laid-back and preserving cultural heritage despite economic pressures.
Thailand and Vietnam are seen as essential partners—admired for opportunity but watched warily for dominance.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Neighbors regard Laos as peaceful and cooperative, albeit economically dependent.
Nightlife is subdued with early curfews; Vientiane has a small bar scene but little late-night energy.
Men typically wear simple collared shirts or uniforms; youth adopt Thai streetwear sparingly.
Women blend sinh skirts and modest blouses with occasional modern fashion in tourist zones.
Popular pastimes include petanque, sepak takraw, temple volunteering, and family picnics by the river.
Board-game cafés are rare, with occasional expat meetups supplying most tabletop opportunities.
Live mor lam and acoustic sets appear in riverfront venues, yet volume restrictions limit variety.
NGO circles and language exchanges run small meetups, though the overall event calendar is sparse.
Trail networks around Luang Prabang, Nam Et-Phou Louey, and the Bolaven Plateau are accessible for weekend adventures.
The Lao People’s Revolutionary Party monopolizes power with no competitive elections.
The state is officially secular, but Buddhist values inform ceremonies and moral messaging.
Collective bargaining is limited and unions are state-affiliated, leaving workers with little recourse.
Policy aligns with Lao People’s Revolutionary Party socialism, prioritizing stability over pluralism.
Civil society is tightly controlled, and criticism of the state can trigger surveillance.
Market reforms attract Chinese and Thai investment, yet state-owned enterprises still dominate key sectors.
The political environment is stable and insulated from unrest, though transparency is limited.
State-run media and village loudspeakers push official narratives daily, leaving little independent journalism.
Messaging centers on party loyalty, development, and social harmony, making critical discourse sensitive.
Basic healthcare and schooling exist but funding gaps limit quality and access.
Citizens rely on state media; grievances are often managed quietly rather than publicly.
Petty bribery and favoritism remain common in permitting and policing.
Officials expect facilitation payments for licensing, and state-owned firms dominate deals.
Expats can find affordable detached homes, but quality varies and insulation is minimal.
Violent crime is rare, yet petty theft and road safety issues require vigilance.
Provincial hospitals lack specialists; serious cases often go to Thailand.
Expats typically rely on private clinics for basics and evacuate to Bangkok for major care.
Formal daycare options are scarce; most families lean on relatives or hired nannies.
Families juggle schooling and healthcare privately, with little state subsidy beyond vaccination programs.
Public schools lag in English and STEM, pushing expats toward costly international programs.
Aside from Vientiane buses and the China–Laos railway, transit is informal tuk-tuks or private vans.
A state-led economy coexists with growing private enterprise, but regulation can be opaque.
Tax filing is manual, and foreign earners often hire local accountants to navigate incentives.
Personal income tax tops out near 24%, though treaty gaps may complicate remote income.
Cash dominates; ATMs work in cities but online payments remain limited.
Local food and services are inexpensive, though imported goods carry a premium.
The pension scheme covers civil servants and formal workers but benefits are modest and coverage incomplete.
There is no dedicated retirement visa; long-term stays require investment or employment ties.
Most foreigners rotate business visas; permanent residency is difficult without deep investment.
Laotians are friendly, yet the state monitors NGOs and media, limiting outspoken activism.
Long-term residence requires annual renewals tied to employment or investment.
Naturalization is rare and demands a decade of residence plus government approval.
Dependents may accompany work permits, but schooling and healthcare arrangements fall on the family.
Paperwork often needs multiple in-person visits and translation fees.
Visa overstays draw fines, and political speech restrictions apply to foreigners.
Laos does not recognize dual citizenship, and naturalization requires renouncing prior passports.
We’d need evacuation insurance, language support, and contingency plans for power and schooling.
There is virtually no local game industry, so Trey would operate entirely remotely.
No internationally recognized studios are based in Laos.
Small co-working spaces host occasional tech meetups, but consistent game-dev groups are rare.
Startup grants are minimal and digital payment penetration is low for monetization.
Vientiane has improving fiber and 4G, yet power grids and roads outside the capital remain fragile.
Chronic life-threatening swings and infrastructure strain make the family question long-term viability without major resiliency investments.
Extreme light swings dominate lifestyle planning with regular sleep disruption and mood crashes even with preparation.
Comfortable days are infrequent; we constantly monitor forecasts to grab the odd mild afternoon.
Survival dominates—frequent trade-offs between rent, food, and healthcare with minimal institutional help.
Lifestyle feels brittle; one unexpected expense forces significant cutbacks or debt.
Luxury services are thin; wealth management and elite schooling often require another city.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Large rentals appear occasionally and move fast, demanding premium rent or broker connections.
Community living is rare and often under-resourced, requiring significant personal effort to sustain.
Interactions feel transactional; expect friendly acquaintances but limited favors or shared childcare.
Anti-immigrant sentiment is common; families feel compelled to downplay their origins.
White migrants are linked to gentrification or colonial histories, prompting cool interactions.
Service norms are pragmatic; smiles and chit-chat are rare outside personal networks.
Depth is limited—most locals keep emotional distance except with lifelong friends.
Our preference for space regularly clashes with local habits, causing friction.
Trust is low; we keep personal matters private to avoid gossip or judgment.
Significant judgment follows casual dress or natural looks.
Harsh judgments around weight or fitness saturate media and daily chatter.
Style conformity is strict; experimentation or casual wear is frowned upon.
Victim-blaming attitudes persist, eroding trust in institutions.
Communities enforce strict gendered behavior with little tolerance for experimentation.
Hostile policies or social norms make non-monogamy extremely risky. non-monogamy acceptance.
Public shaming or policy consequences follow disclosures about casual sex.
Multi-partner households face outright hostility or legal barriers.
Physical proximity is unavoidable in many settings with limited accommodations.
High prevalence of firearms and lax rules elevate daily risk perception.
Harsh sentencing and moral panic dominate political rhetoric.
Aggressive tactics and profiling are common, eroding trust in authorities.
Mass violence risk is an ongoing topic; we regularly rehearse safety plans.
Conditions are degrading with widespread labor exploitation and violence.
Pedestrian deaths or injuries are common; car dominance limits independence.
Public health messaging is uneven; we invest extra time to maintain routines.
Ultra-processed options crowd shelves; schools and events lean heavily on packaged snacks.
Produce quality or range is inconsistent; international cuisine is niche.
Prevalence is high with long waits and patchy insurance coverage.
Higher obesity prevalence indicates limited access to healthy routines in some areas.
Incidence trends upward; access to specialized care may be strained.
Single-industry dominance makes downturns painful and long-lasting.
